designScenario.name: Ignition System
designScenario.description: The Ignition System is responsible for initiating and sustaining combustion in the aircraft engine under all operational conditions. It interfaces with the Engine Control Computer to receive timing and sequencing commands, ensures reliable spark generation across multiple igniter units, and monitors flame stability. Designed for redundancy and fault tolerance, it operates in extreme environmental conditions while maintaining synchronization with engine rotational speed, fuel flow, and altitude parameters.

details.description: Generate high-energy sparks across igniter units with precise timing synchronized to engine RPM and compressor stages.
Automatically adjust ignition frequency and duration based on inputs from the Engine Control Computer during start-up, climb, and relight scenarios.
Maintain dual independent ignition channels with cross-channel monitoring to ensure continuous operation during single-channel failures.
Implement arc fault detection and automatic deactivation of faulty igniter circuits to prevent system-wide failures.
Deliver spark energies ≥ 4 joules per ignition event to ensure reliable combustion at altitudes above 40,000 feet.
Maintain ignition timing accuracy within ±0.5 milliseconds across -40°C to +200°C operational temperature ranges.
Provide capacitive discharge counters and spark energy degradation metrics through the aircraft's central maintenance system.
Support on-wing testing of ignition exciters without engine rotation via built-in test equipment (BITE).

systemComponents.name: Ignition Control Unit
systemComponents.description: Primary controller managing spark timing, energy output, and health monitoring of ignition channels.

subComponents.name: Spark Timing Controller
subComponents.description: FPGA-based module processing engine position signals and calculating ignition advance angles.

subComponents.name: Redundant Controller Module
subComponents.description: Backup control path with independent power supply and signal processing chain.

systemComponents.name: High-Energy Igniter Units
systemComponents.description: Capacitive discharge-based spark generators mounted on engine combustor casing.

subComponents.name: Pulse Transformer
subComponents.description: Steps up input voltage to 20kV range for spark generation.

subComponents.name: Semiconductor Switching Stack
subComponents.description: Thyristor-based array controlling discharge timing and energy.

systemComponents.name: Flame Detection Sensors
systemComponents.description: UV/IR-based sensors monitoring combustion stability in the turbine section.

subComponents.name: Photodiode Array
subComponents.description: Multi-spectral sensor array detecting flame signature wavelengths.

subComponents.name: Signal Processor
subComponents.description: Filters and amplifies raw sensor data for flame presence determination.

systemComponents.name: Ignition Power Supply
systemComponents.description: Dual-redundant 28VDC-to-400VDC converters for exciter capacitor charging.

subComponents.name: High-Voltage Capacitor Bank
subComponents.description: Energy storage system for spark discharge events.

subComponents.name: Voltage Regulation Circuit
subComponents.description: Maintains stable charging voltage across temperature variations.

relationships.description: The Ignition System operates as a subordinate module within the Engine Control Computer architecture.
Spark Timing Controller is an integral sub-component of the Ignition Control Unit.
Receives engine speed and phase reference signals from the Engine Sensor Interface.
Manages and monitors multiple igniter units distributed around the engine combustor.
Requires stable high-voltage input from the Ignition Power Supply for operation.
Transmits combustion stability data to the central diagnostic system for performance monitoring.
